title.narrative: UNDP Support to the Health Sector in Limpopo Phase IV

description.narrative: Support the Department of Health in Limpopo to improve access to quality of health care and service delivery through the recruitment of volunteer health professionals from abroad to address the delivery level problems in hospitals around the province.

title.narrative: UNDP Support to Health Sector in Limpopo
UNDP Support to Health Sector in Limpopo
2009 Project Evaluation: UNDP Support to Health Sector in Limpopo
Terminal Evaluation of the UNDP Support to Health Sector in Limpopo Programme: Phase III
UNDP Capacity Development Partnership in South Africa Monitoring and Evaluation in KwaZulu-Natal Domestication of Millennium Development Goals - Outcome Evaluation
UNDP Capacity Development Partnership in South Africa Monitoring and Evaluation in KwaZulu-Natal Domestication of Millennium Development Goals - Outcome Evaluation: Part II
UNDP SUPPORT TO THE HEALTH SECTOR IN LIMPOPO Health Professionals Volunteerism and Capacity Development - Outcome Evaluation: Part One

description.narrative: This programme is the third phase of the UNV Support to the Health Sector in Limpopo (00039493). It is an extension of Phase 1 and Phase 2, the objective of which is the UNV/UNDP assistance to the Government of South Africa to improve health care service
independent political entity
Accountability - local government finance

1. Number of UNV health professionals recruited to the Health Sector in Limpopo, and the extend they contribute to health service delivery
2. Quality and types of skills transferred to local health professionals and the extend they contribute to local knowledge base
3. Number of events held to promote volunteerism and the extend they impact on locals to volunteer
4. Some form of agreement between UNDP and the province starting 2014

comment.narrative: 2009:The province is largely rural with an estimated population of 5 404 868 people which constitutes 10.4 % of the South African total population. Being a rural province, the resultant brain drain creates a huge shortage of health professionals in the province as health professionals leave the province for better opportunities locally and internationally. Since January 2013, the project's number of UNV health professionals has declined from 48 to 26. The province is also characterised by poor health infrastructure which does not attract health professionals. Volunteerism by local professional is also not common in the province. The current partnership/programme with UNDP ends in 2014. The current partnership programme with UNDP ends in 2014.

1. The fourth partnership programme on health service delivery for Limpopo government developed to support the Provincial Department of Health in meeting health service delivery mandate 2. At least 12 new additional UNV doctors recruited and deployed across the health facilities in the Limpopo

UNDP and UNV have successfully supported the implementation of the programme which continued to the recruit and place UNV health professionals to the Health Sector in Limpopo to strengthen health service delivery, more importantly to the rural communities. Though the target of recruiting and placing of 120 UNVs was not achieved, the programme with the support of the hospital management has led to the establishment of 2 diabetic clinics in Polokwane and Mankweng Hospitals. Two internal medicine specialists are each able to see between 30 and 50 patients per week. The establishment of the clinics was championed by the UNVs as a response to a high incidence of diabetes. The success of this partnership programme also led to the development of the Phase IV programme which started in April 2015.

• 27 UNV doctors (disaggregated by sex) in identified specialties recruited and deployed across the health facilities in Limpopo • A comprehensive health information system developed in partnership with the Human Sciences Research Council (HSRC)

The targets for this programme were not achieved in 2016, primarily due to financial constrained experienced by the Department of Health in Limpopo. However, in 2015, UNDP and the UNV programme have successfully supported the implementation of the programme which continued to recruit and place UNV health professionals to improve access and quality of health service delivery in Limpopo more specifically to the marginalized rural communities. The programme with the support of the hospital management has led to the establishment of 2 diabetic clinics in Polokwane and Mankweng Hospitals. Two internal medicine specialists are each able to see between 30 and 50 patients per week. The establishment of the clinics was championed by the UNVs as a response to a high incidence of diabetes. The success of this partnership programme also led to the development of the Phase IV programme which started in April 2015.

description.narrative: UNDP Support to Health Sector in Limpopo Province - Phase IV

title.narrative: Reducing Disaster Risks from Wildland fire Hazards Assoc

description.narrative: Develop and implement integrated disaster risk management strategies to address climate change-induced fire hazards and risks

title.narrative: Terminal Evaluation Report - Reducing Disaster Risks from Wildfire Hazards Associated with Climate Change (South Africa

description.narrative: Reducing Disaster Risks from Wildfire Hazards Associated with Climate Change in South Africa
independent political entity

2013: 1(a). Number of Fire Protection Associations (FPAs) integrated into and aligned with, the affected structures (including the municipal land use planning, fire brigade and disaster services)
1(b) Ability of regional centers and networks with capacity to effectively respond to extreme weather events.
2. Number of Automated Weather Stations (AWS) recording local weather conditions under a changing climate regime in the high altitude mountain areas of the Fynbos biome.
3.Number of private landowners in FPAs with institutionised proactive risk management measures encouraged by insurance based incentives

comment.narrative:
2012: There is only one Fire Protection Association with inadequate capacity to manage climate-induced windland fires in the Fynbos Biome
2012: Ten automated Weather Stations are currently operational in the Fynbos Biome
2012: Ten private landowners taking proactive risk management measures to prevent wildfire and associated hazard reduction

• Fire Protection Association (FPAs) in two demonstration sites- Overberg and Cape Winelands District Municipalities established • Skills and competency levels of FPA members and fire practitioners in Integrated Fire Management (IFM) developed. • Prospective funding sources and other mechanisms identified to ensure finance sustainability of FPAs in the long term. • Communication and awareness strategy for the FPAs, United Fire Protection Association (UFPAs) and National Fire Protection Association (NFPA)implemented • Test the Fire Protection Management toolbox in Matatiele and Cacadu Districts, respectively

Due to patterns of urbanisation, agriculture and potential impact upon water catchment areas, Fynbos Biome is identified as the most vulnerable region in South Africa with respect to disaster risks from Wildland fire. UNDP/GEF Special Climate Change Fund supported Department of Environmental Affairs to develop and implement integrated disaster risk management strategies to address climate change induced fire hazards and risks through building capacity at local level to manage increased incidence and extent of fires. Six Fire Protection Associations (FPAs) and local authorities, and 1547 stakeholders were trained in integrated fire management in the Fynbos biome of the Western Cape. Two FPAs were established in Overberg and Cape Winelands District Municipalities; a Fire Protection Toolkit and FPA handbook to document best practices in coordinated Integrated Fire management (IFM) implementation, have been produced. Six Advanced Fire Systems (AFIS) terminals have been installed across the Fynbos Biome to enhance fire monitoring and prediction. 50 Automated Weather Stations also installed across the biome to measure local weather conditions.
• End of project evaluation report produced and management responses implemented

Since its inception in April 2012, the project focusing on the Fynbos Biome has now reached far beyond its original area and outcomes, being tested and adapted by fire management agencies nationally, and globally. It has brought together the South African firefighting fraternity in a collaborative attempt to reduce wildland fire risks in a response to climate change, and much of the work that was done has been ground-breaking, setting the path for an advanced level of Integrated Fire Management in South Africa. A Guide to Integrated Fire Management has been produced to be launched in November 2016.

• Recommendations and management responses of Project Terminal Evaluation Report implemented and project financially closed by January 2018 • Draft Deed of Trust and Board of Trustees documentation reviewed in order to ensure a sustainable structure, and compliance, of an endowment trust fund to support a micro-insurance scheme for low-middle income households • Project steering committee post-operational project closure

description.narrative: Develop and implement integrated disaster risk management strategies to address climate changeinduced fire hazards and risks

The total areas burned by nondamaging and damaging combined might not show a significant reduction by the end of the project implementation however the socioeconomic consequences left by nondamaging veld fire and those by catastrophic fires are significantly different

The CSIR is currently busy establishing the amount of area burnt within the Biome during the project period and also 10 years preceding the project They will also try to differentiate between accidental wildfires and prescribed burns This will take some time as burn permits are held within Municipalities and not every permit issued resulted in a fire Results will be available by December 2015

gt50 Automated Weather Stations will be in place to measure local weather conditions

Due to the fluctuation of the Rand vs the US Dollar there are now more funds to purchase 10 additional weather stations The project extension period is providing the time for these to be installed in gap areas across the biome Project consultants are working with stakeholders to identify sites based on operational needs There are currently a number of low lying areas as opposed to high altitude areas that lack accurate real time weather data which hampers FDI predictions and fire fighting operations

description.narrative: Number of private landowners in FPAs instituting proactive risk management measures in response to insurancebased incentives

comment.narrative: lt10 est
gt100 private landowners in FPAs respond positively to insurancebased incentives set up by the project

An ongoing dialogue with SANTAM and now with Mutual Federal together being the two market leaders in shortterm insurance has now secured formal correspondence clarifying the benefits to a landowner of FPA membership including the incentives offered by insurers to a landowner to join a FPA
Based on infield research with FPAs and 5 of the Western Cape FireWise communities strong consumer and commercial interest has been confirmed for two new or amended existing shortterm products one focused on the emerging market and centered around FireWise communities homeowner asset and livestock insurance in a group scheme model with emphasis on fire flood and disaster perils and a second focused on commercial insurance for FPAs themselves This latter product would provide asset insurance third party and liability cover and provide for a certain portion of fire suppression costs a FPA is likely to contract or provide in a season
An outline business case has been prepared for SANTAM to take to Executive level showing the potential for these two new or amended existing products and pathways for development
A similar conversation has been opened with Mutual and Federal and SAFIRE
Submissions have been provided to the Programme for the Insurance component of the Handbook text
A successful meeting with Novitas Capital Advisors was held to plan a workshop for late July on developing the WildFire Disaster Trust Fund and potentially widening the scope to include all forms of disaster not just wildfire much like was accomplished for political risk by the South African Special Risk Insurance Association SASRIA
A Trust attorney has been approached to advise on the establishment of the WildFire Disaster Trust Fund
A presentation to the SAIA Commercial and Personal Lines Technical Committee was delivered see report below

gt60 of the potential landowners within the 2012 Southern Cape FPA and Cedarberg FPA boundaries are paid up and functional FPA members
Accurate statistics will be gleaned from 5 FPAs by December 2015

title.narrative: Market Transformation through Energy Efficiency Standard

description.narrative: The primary objective of the project is to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions caused by the electricity consumption of household appliances in South Africa

title.narrative: Market Transformation through Energy Efficiency Standards and Labelling of Appliances in South Africa
Market Transformation through Energy Efficiency Standard
Market Transformation through Energy Efficiency Standard

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women
total number of people with improved access to energy as a result of UNDP-supported intervention
Policy and regulatory framework for labels and standards
independent political entity
Energy - power generation

1. Evidence of applicable S&L implementing regulations gazetted and enacted
2.Energy classes and MEPS thresholds for the 12 products included in DoE & DTI action plans
3. Number of institutions audited and capacitated
4. Number of consumers and retailers who are made aware of appliance energy efficiency standards and labels
5.Market Surveillance & Compliance (MSC) procedures adopted and implemented

comment.narrative:
2013: Insufficient or out-dated policy/regulatory framework to implement Standards & Labelling to address the current challenges on energy and electricity.
2013: Labelling specifications and MEPs are unknown.
2013: There are no accredited institutions for testing and enforcement of standards and labels
2013: There is limited awareness amongst consumers and retailers on energy efficiency
2013: No Standards and Labels in place .

• Report on policy review on the implications of incentives to increase uptake of energy efficient appliances • Minimum energy performance standards for electric geysers promulgated • Assess, guide facility design and upgrade of test facilities to meet energy performance testing requirement and accreditation • Communications campaign developed to raise awareness on energy efficiency standards • Market surveillance procedures based on South Africa and international experiences developed

There has been a gradual increase in the energy efficiency in the residential sector of listed appliances in the country without regulations. This was largely influenced by compelling trading policies in the European Union (EU) and global advancements in technology. Through the UNDP/GEF support, minimum energy performance standards (MEPS) for 10 of the 11 listed appliances were drafted and promulgated, with the exception of electric geysers which is currently being amended to have a higher energy efficiency specification. MEPS for electric water heaters were ultimately set for energy class B, which is a level higher than the level C recommended in the FRIDGE study. These MEPS are planned to be implemented in 2016 and the appliances are projected to reduce electricity demand and GHG emissions by 5.55 TWh and 5.49 million tCO2eq by 2030.

• A signed MoA between DoE and the South African Bureau of Standards (SABS) • The South African Energy Label launched by the Minister of Energy and implemented • Policy review of proposed incentives to increase the uptake of energy efficient appliances • Minimum energy performance standards (MEPS) for electric geysers are included in the NRCS’s technical regulations and amendment of standard for geysers (SANS 151) • SABS test facility accredited for the testing of energy efficient appliances and training of staff • Top distributors and retail staff trained on the energy efficiency label guideline

Following the signing of the Memorandum of Agreement (MoA) between the Department of Energy (DoE) and the South African Bureau of Standards (SABS) in January 2016, SABS was contracted to procure project goods and services and to be a project fund administrator.
In March 2016, the South African Energy Label and an accompanying ‘Save Energy’ logo was launched by Energy Minister during the Africa Utility Week in Cape Town. This energy efficiency initiative has led to the introduction of a campaign called Appliance Check to raise awareness of the use of the label and the benefits of using energy efficient appliances. Labels are attached to appliances that have been designed to meet minimum energy efficiency standards, which include air conditioners, washing machines, electric ovens, refrigerators, electric geysers, audio and video equipment, dishwashers and electric lamps. A few of our government buildings are already leading by example in terms of being green and energy efficient. These include [the DoE’s] Environmental House, [the Department of Public Service and Administration’s] Batho Pele House and Freedom Park in Pretoria.
As part of policy review for increasing the uptake of energy efficient appliances in South Africa, UNDP facilitated the appointment of Ernst and Young to firstly identify the incentive schemes for energy efficient electrical appliances that should be considered for further evaluation. The evaluation will assess the feasibility of the implementation of the identified incentive schemes following a Cost Benefit Analysis (CBA) and impact assessment methodologies. The recommendations from this evaluation will contribute in the development of a business case.
MEPS for electric geysers were also promulgated during 2016. This led to the amendment of the VC 9006 and the MEPS were increased to energy class B as recommended by the engineering and economic impact study for electric geysers conducted in 2014. The Department of Energy has also finalised

• DoE to collaborate with Government Communication Information Services (GCIS) and SABS on a large awareness campaign/roadshows • Market surveillance and compliance (MSC) procedures and systems put in place, and institutionalised • Recommendations of the 2016 project audit report implemented • An independent Terminal Evaluation team recruited towards project closure in September 2017 to conduct end of project evaluation

description.narrative: Adopt labeling specifications and MEPS thresholds for the 12 products selected for SL regulations
Labelling energy classes and MEPS adopted

comment.narrative: None

Implementation of energy classes and MEPS thresholds
Agreement with stakeholders on schedule to phase out inefficient appliances

The technical regulation VC 9008 which is guided by SANS 941 covering 10 of the listed appliances and includes the use of the label was promulgated in November 2014 The effective date for the enforcement of the regulations was May 29 2014 for standby power and the effective date for the other appliances under VC9008 will be enforced from February 2016
The technical regulations for lamps VC8043 which is intended to remove inefficient electric lamps from the market are now in force

description.narrative: Conduct market and engineering analysis for the products selected for SL regulation

Cost benefits analysis conducted for the 12 products selected for SL regulation
Number of market research and industry studies conducted
Market transformation benefits demonstrated to stakeholders

comment.narrative: None
Propose energy classes and MEPS thresholds applicable for the South African market

A study on the engineering and economic impacts of introducing energy efficient electric geysers led by the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and Linkd a service provider commissioned by the project concluded that the efficiency of electric geysers can be improved to energy class B This was a level higher than the energy class C recommended during the FRIDGE study
The study further concluded that the cost for the incremental improvements on geysers will be about R30000 for increasing the insulation thickness of a 150 litre geyser to 50 mm
A consultative process to amend the compulsory specifications for geysers has commenced

comment.narrative: None

A statistically relevant sample of households will be drawn on to determine the market penetration effectiveness of the project
Ensure consumers distinguish between MEPS extra financial benefits of exceeding MEPS voluntarily
At minimum the staff of top 10 manufacturers distributors are aware about SL programmes

The project experienced serious delays in the appointment of a communications company to assist with development and implementation of a communications plan and this has affected the anticipated awareness raising on the imminent implementation of the MEPS and the consumer benefits of using energy efficient appliances These delays have stemmed from a lack of agreement on the cash transfer modalities between DoE and UNDP
In August 2015 DoE finally formally requested UNDP to assist with the procurement of the communications company and is in the process of appointing SABS as project fund administrator The agreement between DoE and SABS has been approved by the DoE DirectorGeneral and forwarded to SABS for countersignature
The procurement of a communications company through UNDP has begun and two companies have been shortlisted and invited to present before a preferred bidder is announced

description.narrative: Evaluation of financial incentives such as the rebate program operated by the Eskom DSM for purchasing efficient appliances Development of new financial incentives if needed
Number of existing rebate programs

comment.narrative: Current ESKOM rebate programme
Increase in market share of efficient appliances

The projectsupported incentives study recommended four incentive schemes
A standard offer for LED lights
Subsidisation of electric geysers
A swap programme for refrigerators
A rebate system for purchasing energy efficient appliances above the MEPS
In addition to the above the study further recommended that government needs to lead by example and should set up a procurement policy that will compel state organs to purchase energy efficient appliances and equipment
Terms of reference for the review of the proposed incentives and the development of a business case funding model and running a pilot to test the viability of the incentives schemes have been prepared

description.narrative: Integration of product energy performance compliance checking with local manufacturers and country preimport inspections
MSC procedures implemented

comment.narrative: None
Develop database of SL products

The baseline determination process to ascertain the projected electricity demand reduction and related GHG emission reductions resulting from improvements in energy efficiency of listed appliances commenced in the third quarter of 2014
The baseline project went through a consultative process with key stakeholders to determine the database use cases
The second phase of project activities focused on developing the database specifications and methodology for populating the database This led to the development of database schemadiagram listing required data for the 12 appliances
Training on the use and querying of the database was conducted in February 2015 following the handover of the database to DoE DoE will provide further access to the database by other government institutions as may be required
A workshop with manufacturers to discuss requirements for annual submission of appliance data was held in February 2015
Energy data collected during the baseline study was used to calculate energy and GHG emission reduction

description.narrative: Reduce greenhouse gas GHG emissions caused by the electricity consumption of household appliances in South Africa by facilitating a comprehensive transformation of the home appliance market through the introduction of a combination of two regulatory tools Minimum Energy Performance Standards and Information Labels SL and a series of associated awarenessbuilding and monitoring activities

kWh of electricity demand reduction in the residential sector by year 5 of project implementation
Tons of CO2 emissions reduction by year 5 of the project implementation

comment.narrative: The average efficiency of most appliances sold in SA is lower than the previous European class G

Increase awareness of energy efficiency
Increase market share of high efficient appliances
Reduce electricity demand by 441 TWh over the project time
Reduce CO2 emissions by 454 MtCo2 over the project time

The baseline study concluded that there has been a gradual increase in the energy efficiency of the appliances covered by the project This increase in performance was largely influenced by policy developments in the EU and by advancements in technology Appliances that still had potential for improvement were air conditioners refrigerators and electric water heaters Minimum Energy Performance Standards MEPS set for these appliances were projected to reduce electricity demand and GHG emissions by 555 TWh and 549 million tCO2eq in 2013 respectively
New MEPS for 10 of the 12 listed appliances were promulgated in November under the National Regulator for Compulsory Specifications NRCS technical regulation VC 9008 The effective date for enforcement of the regulations is set for February 2016
New energy performance levels for incandescent lights which are intended to remove less efficient lights were enforceable from August 2014
MEPS for electric water heaters were ultimately set for energy class B which is a level higher than the level C recommended in the FRIDGE study A process to amend VC 9006 and incorporate the new MEPS has been initiated in consultation with affected manufacturers

The findings of the GIZ study that South Africa has adequate policies and regulatory framework to support the introduction of energy efficiency in household appliances were accepted by the PSC with a proviso that new policies for incentives may need to be considered in the future
Manufacturers and importers of listed white goods and audiovisual equipment were consulted in the development of test procedures and the setting of MEPS and related regulations
A consultative process with manufacturers was followed in determining the energy efficient class for electric geysers three workshops were held with manufacturers leading to the agreement of energy class B

description.narrative: Strengthen employee skills

Train the required number of people based on sales number of units to be tested per year
Train all staff involved on testing and enforcement on accreditation requirements constraints
Adoption of conversion factors for testing considering the South African conditions
Train the required number of inspectors for trade inspections and compliance checking

Intertek also trained SABS staff on refrigeration dish washers and standby power This training forms part of the trainthetrainer programme in which trained senior staff members conduct inhouse training to their colleagues
One SABS staff has also undertaken training on air conditioners and has visited other test facilities to gather technical information on the design of the air conditioner test chamber pressure vessel and suction box
Four NRCS staff members have since undertaken a study visit to South Korea The visit had the following objectives
i To introduce NRCS staffinspectors to energy efficiency mandatory requirements and product labelling
ii To familiarise inspectors with energy efficiency test procures and verification of compliance
iii To observing and participate in market surveillance and enforcement activities to ensure compliance with energy efficiency regulations
Participants visited the KTL Test Facility the South Korean regulator KEMCO and a manufacturing plant LG
Two workshops with local and international experts on economic incentives and compliance enforcement were held on August 27 and 28 2015 respectively Participants included the representatives from NRCS CLASP SEAD University of Pretoria National Treasury the DTI DoE and SL project managers from Ghana Kenya India and China
A fourday study mission to the UK was undertaken in July July 28 31 Participants to the study mission were selected from the SL Project Steering Committee PSC and Working Groups established under the PSC The selection was guided by the missions objectives and the areas of interest that would be covered during the mission Based on these criteria the following institutions participated in the mission
i National Regulator for Compulsory Specifications
ii United Nations Development Programme
iii South African Bureau of Standards
iv Department of Trade Industry
v Department of Environment
vi Department of Energy
vii Eskom
The study mission had the following objectives
i To introduce participants to policies supportive of the SL project
ii To discuss potential incentives for manufacturers and consumers
iii To discuss and share experiences on monitoring and enforcement regimes supportive of the SL project
iv To identify areas of future collaboration on key project areas

At least 50 of consumers and retailers contacted within the sample group become more aware of appliance energy efficiency standards and labels and retailers provide evidence of marketing efforts to support the scheme

The services of the DoE communications service provider could not be procured during the second and third quarters of 2014 A request was later made by DoE to obtain UNDPs assistance with procurement of an SL project communications service provider for the development and implementation of the project communications plan This request was however halted on DoEs subsequent instruction in September 2014
The DoEs communications terms of reference were not approved by the DoE Bid Adjudication Committee Instead a recommendation to prioritise activities for the first quarter of 2015 was made The finalisation of the label design development of the label guideline and launch of the label were also prioritised for 2015
DoE requested UNDP to resume the procurement of a communications company in May 2015 a process that is now underway

description.narrative: Define labeling specifications and MEPS thresholds for the 12 products considered by the DoE DTI for SL regulation
Energy classes and MEPS thresholds for the 12 products included in DoE DTI action plan

comment.narrative: Labelling specifications and MEPS are unknown
By 2012 reach an agreement with stakeholders on energy classes and MEPS requirements for the 12 products included in DoE DTI action plan

MEPS threshold for 11 appliances have been defined and have been discussed with the affected manufacturers and other industry players
The promulgated energy classes
Air conditioners Energy efficiency rating of Class B
Audio and video equipment standby power of 1W or less
Large electric ovens Efficiency rating of Class B
Small Medium electric ovens Energy Class A
Refrigerators Energy efficiency rating of Class B
Freezers Energy efficiency rating of Class C
Dishwashers Energy efficiency rating of Class A
Washing Machines Energy efficiency rating of Class A
Washerdryer combinations Efficiency rating of Class A
Tumbledryers Energy efficiency rating of Class D
Electric geysers Energy efficiency rating of Class B
While the energy class for electric geysers has been agreed with manufacturers the process of amending the geyser technical regulations is still underway
Work on finalising the label design and developing a label guideline that will be used in printing labels for the different appliances has begun This work will culminate with a launch of the label in September 2015
The Working Group on Specifications and Labelling is currently considering the recent announcement by the European Commission to ditch the A grading and revert to the A G grading The South African label and MEPS threshold are based on the EU directives and changes in the EU energy efficiency grading system will require changes to the label design and the testing standards may need to be reviewed

description.narrative: Development of Monitoring and Evaluation ME capacity
Skilled South African professionals trained on ME of energy projects

comment.narrative: Limited
All those skilled South African professionals trained demonstrate appropriate level of knowledge

Work for this Outcome has not commenced However the project underwent a midterm review during the second quarter of 2015 and a management response to the midterm review was prepared and uploaded to the UNDP ERC website The MTR devoted considerable attention to the issue of professional training and capacity needs of stakeholders

description.narrative: Implementation of SL Market Surveillance Compliance MSC regime to ensure energy performance standards is met

MSC procedures adopted and implemented

comment.narrative: None

Negotiations with the UK National Measurement Office to assist improvement in the monitoring and enforcement regime of the NRCS did not materialise and NRCS has commenced with selfassessment NRCSs assessment will be presented in the next PSC meeting

description.narrative: Policy and regulatory framework for the SL program Strengthen structures and mechanisms for appliance energy efficiency standards and labels SL

Evidence of applicable SL implementing regulations gazetted and enacted
Evidence that relevant regulations are disseminated to key industry stakeholders

comment.narrative: Insufficient policyregulatory framework to implement SL programme
Policy institutional regulatory framework on energy efficient appliances is gazetted and enacted into law under the National Energy Act by end of 2013

The existing regulatory framework under the NRCS remains relevant for setting up minimum energy performance standards
Regulations introducing new energy performance standards for all listed appliances are now in place These include VC 9008 for all listed white goods and audiovisual equipment VC8043 which set performance standards for incandescent lights and VC9006 for electric water heaters
VC 9008 is already enforceable for standby power and the enforcement date for the remainder of the appliances under this VC will be from February 2016
VC 8043 on incandescent lamps has been enforced since August 2014
VC 9006 is undergoing amendments to increase the MEPS to energy class B as recommended by the engineering and economic impact study for electric geysers conducted in 2014

comment.narrative: None

Accreditation of testing facilities public private and enforcement institution
Adaptation of InternationalEU test procedures to the South African climatic and usage conditions when needed

A survey on the readiness of test facilities was conducted during the second quarter of 2014 Results of the readiness survey indicated that all South African test facilities were upgrading their facilities in anticipation of the new energy efficiency testing requirements
The South African Bureau of Standards SABS was however ahead in terms of required test equipment and staff readiness to test Gerotek and Test Africa two private sector testing labs indicated that they would need assistance from the project for gap analysis and staff training

description.narrative: Strengthened Public Sector Delivery and Democratic Governance
independent political entity
Accountability - local government finance

1. Extent in which the public sector institutional capacity has been strengthened 2. Extent in which local knowledge has been expanded to improve governance and performance of the public sector 3. Progress made on institutionalization of key support programmes to improve service delivery and good governance 4. Extent to which government has been supported to reposition the public sector 5. Number of training modules developed & facilitators trained at the KZN Academy 6. progress made on the production of the KZN Human Development Index Report 7. Extent to which KZN province M&E institutional capacity has been enhanced to improve governance & service delivery

comment.narrative: • 8.8% decrease in average citizen satisfaction between 2009-2012 due to uneven access & low quality of services; & limited capacity of oversight bodies. • 73 % of eligible voters voted in national elections in 2014, & 57% in local government elections in 2011 • Uneven access & quality of services across 3 spheres of government due to inadequate provincial institutional capacity for a developmental state; & inadequate monitoring & evaluation capacity & systems to produce evidence-based human development information to inform strategic planning processes & policies

• Parliament -Interagency Capacity Building & support programme developed & implemented • Legislatures Consultation: Migration • EAD Desk Review Report • IEC Support Programme (2015-2019) • Programme Implementation Preparation Manager appointed to institutionalize the programme ( resource mobilization, key stakeholder identification and management, facilitate recruitment of required expertise, establish office, 2016 AWP etc.)
• KZN Programme of Support ( Prodoc 2015-2017/8) • Provincial public sector capacity needs assessment & Integrated HRD Report ,& Professional Support Programme for • • Provincial and Local Government Managers, aligned to the PGDP & NDP • RBM training material ,training of facilitators/trainees

A provincial Results Based Management/Monitoring and Evaluation capacity assessment was undertaken to inform the Provincial Public Service Training Academy future training scope and approach on RBM/M&E. The assessment recommended a need to for a comprehensive approach to RBM/M&E capacity development and system development that includes the Premier’s Office, provincial government departments, and municipalities. The RBM curriculum and training material for long and short courses has been developed and approved by the UNDP and Academy. The planned training of 40 officials could not take place due to the fact the province wanted to allign the training with the national department’s planning, monitoring and evaluation training framework that has recently been developed. The UNDP and the Academy held a meeting on 19 November 2015, and agreed that the training will take place in the first quarter of 2016. Training material on ethics, integrity and anti-corruption has also been developed, and it was initiallay planned to be conducted in November 2015 targetting 40 officials, and has been defferred to February 2016. Three meetings were held with the province this year. The 2015-2017 project document has been developed and finalised, and agreed to by UNDP and the ACADEMY, and will be delivered on a cost sharing basis (an estimated total amount of $190 166). Provision has been made for three outputs to be delivered during this period, viz. Training and capacity development on RBM and anti corruption and ethics (targeting 40 officials in each respective programme); African leadership programme that will target 96 officials in the province, and the development of the HRD and professional support programme

• 80 senior managers trained in M&E, and Ethics and Anti-corruption • 96 senior managers undertaken a leadership development programme • Draft integrated human resource development strategy • 30 officials from the Southern Africa region trained in UNPAN portal knowledge exchange • Functional AIDS Councils with operational plans • At least 1 pilot on stigma Index implemented • Draft NSP 2017/2020 • Support SA-IAWJ to hold a satellite session on HIV and the Law • Capacity of SA-IAWJ built to effectively address HIV, gender and human rights within the judiciary and wider society • Gender, HIV and capital projects integrated into university curriculum

43 officials attended the annual UNPAN SADC region workshop which served as a platform for countries to benchmark amongst each other and beyond in their progress in embracing and entrenching information sharing and public sector innovation. This is in line with the CPSI’s work in partnership with the UNDP, to promote south-south learning on innovative public administration practices.
All the representatives had the sights set beyond the workshop to chart a way forward in various ways. Mauritius and Lesotho undertook to host one of the UNPAN workshop in future. Tanzania and Mozambique resolved on marketing the portal and make it available for public use. Zambia promised to intensify its efforts to implement their programme of the Kaizen method. Malawi resolved on lobbying government leaders and decision-makers for support and buy-in. While Seychelles would improve collaboration with CPSI specifically on strengthening the e-learning project in the country.
The workshop had made such impact that Namibia resolved to create a database of UNPAN focal persons and share information on the portal. Zambia echoed the commitment while at the same time promising to ensure wider usage of their portal by all ministries.

• Capacity Development Programme implemented to improve the performance of the KwaZulu-Natal Provincial Administration • Public Sector funding innovation guide/policy developed to institutionalise Public Sector Innovation in South Africa and the Region • South African Association of Women Judges and the Private Sector capacitated to mainstream gender within the public sector policy • The South African National AIDS Council (SANAC) supported to finalise and implement the New National Strategic Plan on HIV, STIs and TB (2017 - 2022) • Public Administration norms and standards established to support reform of public service across all three spheres of government

description.narrative: Enhanced Public Accountability and Community Engagement
independent political entity
Accountability - local government finance

1. Extent to which legislative capacity & knowledge base for oversight & participation in global fora has been expanded
2. Extent to which national & regional institutional capacity has been strengthened and knowledge exchange expanded to improve on electoral management, and citizen participation
3. Extent to which the CPSI institutional capacity has been enhanced; its knowledge networks have been expanded; & innovation has been mainstreamed in the public sector

comment.narrative:
• 5th Parliament Strategic Objectives: Strengthen Oversight & Accountability, Enhanced Public Involvement, Deepening Engagement in International Fora, Strengthening Legislative Capacity
• Declining Voter-Turn out since 1994, and increasing IEC support to regional electoral processes
• CPSI mandate to identify, support and nurture innovation in the public service, with a view to improve service delivery, and provide the public sector with independent, diverse and forward-looking research and advice on innovative service delivery with a specific focus on government’s priorities.

• Parliament -Interagency Capacity Building & support programme developed & implemented • Legislatures Consultation: Migration • EAD Desk Review Report • IEC Support Programme (2015-2019) • Programme Implementation Preparation Manager appointed to institutionalize the programme ( resource mobilization, key stakeholder identification and management, facilitate recruitment of required expertise, establish office, 2016 AWP etc.)

A concept paper was developed, a meeting held with the Secretary of Parliament in September and identified areas include capacity building of staff, and that of portfolio committees, especially targeting and starting with the Chairpersons. The 2015-2019 strategic priorities and plan was shared with the UNDP, and a joint programme that include support to parliament’s participation effectively on SDGS and climate change issues developed and discussed in the SCF Results Group meeting in December 2015. Following another UNDP meeting with the Speaker of Parliament in November, UNDP asked to provide technical and resource support to a high level panel that will look into the impact of legislation over the last 21 years. An MOU between UNDP and Parliament drafted, which will include the support to the Speakers Forum high level panel, and other joint areas identified for implementation in 2016. Support was ready to be provided to the hosting of the international conference on statelessness that was co-hosted by Parliament, but UNHCR HQ steeped in to provide the necessary resources. Following the signing of the MOU, and the request from IEC for support, a Logframe that captures all areas of support was developed by the Country Office, and endorsed by the IEC. Following the endorsement of the Logframe, the CO approached HQs for a technical support to develop a project document on support to the IEC. A UNDP Project Document Formulation Mission was deployed to Pretoria, South Africa for five working days, from 13-17 April, to support the Country Office in developing the project document for the planned new electoral assistance project that intends to provide support to the Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) and other relevant stakeholders within the civil society, the government and the educational sector. The EAD Review Report was produced, together with the Mission report. The project document has been developed and submitted to IEC for review, with the desk top revi

Nine provincial hearings held and submissions received (needs more description) At least 50% of public participants in public hearings be women and youth Programme Officer and CTA appointed (too activity focused, we can exclude from this list) Donors roundtable (what is the outcome of the roundtable, that would be the target) IEC Programme designed in 3 areas (local government elections; domestic observation; regional exchange)

Four hearings held thus far, Eastern Cape in East London, the Northern Cape at Kimberley, the Free State in Bloemfontein and KwaZulu-Natal in Durban. People have spoken passionately about their lived experiences and difficulties with some of the laws introduced since 1994. They have also come up with proposed solutions to improve specific laws and their application. No tangible results thus far. Urgent problems that have been identified by the Panel are already being passed over to the relevant government departments for consideration and review. In the four public hearings held thus far people have spoken passionately about their lived experiences and difficulties with some of the laws introduced since 1994. The citizens have come up with proposed solutions to improve specific laws and their application. About 100 laws passed since 1994 have been identified for special consideration and review. (see attached column by the Chair of the Panel on progress made)
No record of the breakdown of participants in the public hearings, but the majority of participants have been women and young people. Key issues raised based on peoples own lived experiences are access to land, unemployment, gender discrimination and sexual abuse, and access to education. Which affect young people and women.

description.narrative: 1. Extent to which institutional capacity has been expanded to disability policy, programmes and allocation of resources

comment.narrative: 2013: Inadequate institutional capacity to plan and implement disability policy, programmes and allocation of resources.
National Disability Rights Policy (NDRP) developed and approved by Cabinet

The final draft of the National Disability Rights Policy (NDRP) has been submitted to Cabinet for approval. The Policy will ensure that SA honours its obligations under the International Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, to which it is a signatory. UNDP supported the DSD to develop a disability rights monitoring and evaluation framework which is being used to track progress in eradicating inequalities and reducing poverty among people with disabilities and their families. Aspects of the M&E indicator matrix, in-depth analysis of disability disaggregation of the NDP as well as elements of the Cost of Disability research were used in the drafting of the Policy. The Department of Higher Education and Training (DHET) is also making extensive use of the statistical information generated by this joint programme to develop a disability mainstreaming policy for all post-school education and training programmes to addressing disability within post-school institutions.
Launch of the National Disability Right Policy in March 2016

The United Nations Country Team (UNCT), in collaboration with then Department of Women, Children and Persons with Disabilities (DWCPD), solicited funding from the United Nations Programme on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UNPRPD) to develop a joint programme of support to enhance and accelerate UN support for the implementation of the CRPD in South Africa for the achievement of the following three complementary outcomes: (1) Strengthen monitoring and evaluation capacity for effective oversight and advocacy for promotion of the rights of persons with disabilities; (2) Establish a CRPD compliant legal and policy framework to implement provisions of the CRPD in South Africa; and (3) Reduce economic vulnerability of persons with disabilities.
UNDP served as the lead agency also responsible for the achievement of outcome 1 and supported the development and management of the M&E aspect of the project; OHCHR which has extensive experience and expertise on international standards and legislations on the rights of people with disabilities focused on outcome 2 implementation; and UNICEF has experience and technical expertise on child-disability issues and focused on the achievement of outcome 3. Technical expertise on the needs for women with disabilities was sourced from UNFPA and UN Women. The Project was implemented in collaboration various stakeholders in Government (including the Departments of Social Development (lead), International Relations and Cooperation, Justice and Constitutional Development, and Statistics South Africa); Human Rights Institutions (South African Human Rights Commission, and Commission on Gender Equality); and Civil Society (South African Disability Alliance, Disabled People South Africa, and National Chapter of Users and Survivors of Psychiatry).
The Project has achieved the following milestones:
• A White Paper on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities was approved by the South African Cabinet approved new policy that promotes,
• Joint UN/Gov project proposal for disability Phase II developed • Disability Machinery capacitated to coordinate the implementation of the CRPD

The project focus on provision of technical assistance, knowledge exchange and stakeholder management to promote rural development and equitable access to land in order to address poverty and underdevelopment in rural areas.

Support the Department of Rural Development and Land Reform to develop an Integrated Comprehensive Rural Development Strategy
policy, planning and administration

• Number of studies conducted on the land size efficiency and technology appropriate to be used by smallholder farmers. • Number of International Exchange Programmes supported to share global experiences on land reform programmes

comment.narrative: Unequal access to land remains one of the major causes of poverty in South Africa with 13% of the land allocated to Africans is not productive and government did not provide any support to improve productivity in this land.
Project was not implemented pending the signing of cost sharing agreement
Project was not implemented pending the signing of cost sharing agreement

• Studies conducted on the land size efficiency and technology appropriate to be used by smallholder farmers. • Two International Exchange Programmes supported to share global experiences on land reform programmes • A PMU established at the Department of Rural Development and Land Reform (DRDLR) to oversee the implementation of the project

UNDP, as a member of the Technical Working Group provided technical advice and support to government in conducting socio-economic impact assessment of two Land Reform Bills. The intention of the bills is to address land tenure insecurity throughout South Africa that continues to act as a stumbling block to adequate socio-economic redress and transformation in land ownership patterns and improve livelihoods of people living in rural areas. It is estimated that more 22 million people (40% of the total population) living in rural areas are without secure property rights, enacting these bills into law will improve access to land and subsequently improve their livelihoods. In addition, UNDP provided technical advice to Government on a bill regulating land holdings, which seeks to restrict foreign ownership of land and impose land ceilings in order to redistribute the surplus land to smallholder farmers.

• Policy support provided to Department of Rural Development and Land Reform (DRDLR) to facilitate access to land • An economic simulation model developed on land size and efficiencies • An International Exchange Programme established to share international experience on land reform programmes • Support provided to develop an EU and DRDLR Cooperation Project • Technical assistance provided in closing the Belgian Project on Land Reform Beneficiaries
